title: Warwickshire Centenary Way Walking Route

images.title: Dennis Turner / Warwickshire Centenary Way
images.caption: Part of the 98 mile long Warwickshire Centenary Way close to Northend village. Due west of this point, the M40 motorway crosses the grid square.

images.title: Michael Dibb / Centenary Way
images.caption: On a frosty morning, the Centenary Way passes Castle Farm.

images.title: Michael Dibb / Centenary Way
images.caption: The path crosses the stream and continues on its (muddy) way.

images.title: Robin Stott / Centenary Way heads for Kenilworth
images.caption: The trail heads for Kenilworth. Seen from a mound beside Middle Woodloes. The pylon on the left marks a sharp change of direction of the power lines. The woods are part of the complex shown on OS as Larch Covert.

images.title: Walking towards the windmill on Windmill Hill, Compton Wynyates by Colin Park, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Tysoe Windmill. You will pass close to this photogenic in the village of Middle Tysoe. The mill is located just to the south of the village and worth a small detour for the views from the 184 metre high windmill hill.

images.title: John Smith / Bridge over the mill stream
images.caption: Bridge over the mill stream. Footbridge forming part of The Centenary Way at Fell Mill, River Stour.

images.title: Centenary Way towards Honington by David P Howard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Centenary Way towards Honington. Grassy footpath and country view in early spring.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / The Coventry Canal, Bedworth, Warwickshire
images.caption:
The Coventry Canal, Bedworth. This just north of Bulkington Bridge (No 14).
The Act of Parliament enabling the construction of the Coventry Canal was passed in 1768, and construction as far as Atherstone by 1771 was followed by the company running out of money and the sacking of James Brindley. One of the purposes of the canal was to provide Coventry with a regular supply of cheap coal from the Bedworth coalfield, which it already did by 1769.
The towpath here is used as part of The Centenary Way, a long distance walking path covering about 100 miles in Warwickshire.

description: Starting at Kingsbury Water Park (video below) in the north of the county this lovely walk takes you through the River Tame Valley, Atherstone Ridge, Nuneaton , Coombe Abbey Park at Coventry (video below), Kenilworth , Warwick , Leamington Spa , Burton Dassett Hills , Avon Dassett , Edge Hill , Shipston on Stour and Ilmington Downs. The route then finishes at Upper Quinton on the edge of the Cotswolds, just south of Stratford Upon Avon . Highlights include the historic castles in Warwick and Kenilworth plus lovely riverside sections along the River Avon and River Leam. There's also some lovely Cotswolds scenery and typical pretty villages with thatched cottages and Norman churches. The path is well waymarked with a green and white disc picturing a bear.
